model_response: Certainly! The experimental arm is called "Internet-Behavioral Cough Suppression Therapy" (iBCST). It is a behavioral intervention that aims to reduce cough frequency and severity by changing the behavior of the participant. The intervention is delivered online through a website and consists of educational and training videos, as well as training exercises. The videos and exercises are designed to teach participants how to suppress their cough using behavioral techniques such as diaphragmatic breathing, cough re-education, and cough hygiene. Participants are also encouraged to keep a cough journal to track their cough frequency and severity. The intervention is designed to be self-administered, but participants will have access to a study therapist through email and phone to ask questions and receive support. The intervention will last for 12 weeks, and participants will be asked to log into the website and watch the videos and perform the exercises as recommended.

In the sham comparator arm, participants will have access to five sham treatment-specific videos ranging from 2-5 minutes in length. The videos will discuss daily training exercises that should take no more than a few minutes to complete. Participants will also be asked to complete a progress check question each week to indicate their adherence to the program.

It is important to have both the experimental and sham comparator arms in this trial to ensure that any observed effects are due to the experimental intervention and not due to other factors such as the placebo effect. The sham comparator arm will serve as a control group to compare the results with the experimental arm. This will help to establish the efficacy of the experimental intervention and its superiority over the sham comparator.

Yes, that is the plan. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental or sham comparator arm in a 1:1 ratio. The randomization will be stratified by gender and age (<65 years or ≥65 years) to ensure balance across the groups.

Interferential therapy is a form of electrotherapy that involves the application of two or more electrodes to the body. The parameters that can be adjusted include the frequency, pulse width, and duty cycle. The frequency is the number of times the current changes direction per second, and it is typically set between 50 and 100 Hz. The pulse width is the duration of each current flow, and it is typically set between 100 and 200 μs. The duty cycle is the ratio of the current "on" time to the total cycle time, and it is typically set between 50% and 100%.
